text: Naples starting best way to do 6 day amalfie coast drive .bus or by sea ..any recommended

Advice please 🙂 I’m heading to Italy next month on a group tour with my Mom. One day is a “choice between”- sail to Capri, or spend the day in Positano. We chose Capri as we figured that would be easier to do pre-booked through the tour. However, we do not want to miss out on Positano. Our hotel is in Sorrento, am I correct the only way to get to Positano is by ferry? If so, is that something I pre-book? Mom and I will be venturing out on our own during a free afternoon. Thanks so much!

comments.comment_text: The ferry is about 40 min each way! We pre booked on ferry hopper then went to the stand to get the tickets. You really only need to prebook about the day before and you also don’t need a full day in Positano in my option. Our sail around Capri was our favorite day of our 17 day Italy trip!
There is also a bus from Sorrento to Amalfi that stops in Positano. Beautiful drive. Especially if you go all the way to Amalfi

Enjoy we did a group tour and had the best time we are still friends with most of the people that were on that tour 10 years later we are heading back again in Sept and doing on our own but the tour was amazing
Capri!
Also by bus, I would bus from Sorrento to Positano then you can catch a ferry to Capri & also get a ferry back to Sorrento
Positano is a short drive from Sorrento. Capri is about an hour ferry ride.
I highly recommend positano! But stray away from the touristy areas of positano! Positano was a dream for me!
Also - just do your research if you decide the bus route! I’ve heard horror stories so we avoided (did private driver one way) just due to crowds, lines, motion sickness etc!

We hired a taxi driver to take us from Sorrento all along the Amalfi coast. The taxi company was recommended in a book but I can’t remember the name of the book or the taxi company. 😬 Our driver was great and stopped along the way for photo ops. Beware: Positano is ALL stairs. If that’s not a problem, it’s well worth the visit. Enjoy!
Private driver from Sorrento to Positano
August is peak tourist season...it will be overcrowded so altghout there are buses to Positano, take a ferry or boat

text: Three friends and I are starting to plan a trip to Italy for 2025. What is the best time to go if we want to avoid the extreme heat but still find it warm enough to swim? September? October? BTW-we’re all 55 plus and the heat is hard on us. Many thanks!

comments.comment_text: We were a group of 7 seniors. We went in September and found it awesome weather wise.
I like going first or second week of June.
I’ve been 5 times Oct was the best weather
September is perfect , sunny but not hot , good water temperature
June or september
Definitely September, we went 4 weeks each time in 2019 & 2022, perfect warm weather, sunny & blue skies all the way. But not too hot.
April was perfect last year!
June you're likely to find better weather (and longer days), in September the water temperature is likely to be warmer.

Definitely Mid-September! It is relentless and unbearable to come to Italy from Mid- June to August. You wont be able to go sightseeing much due to the heat and people stay indoors from 11 til 7pm due to the heat. Forget going to the beach as well… And if you are menopausal, forget it.
We went for the second half of September into early October 2022. We had great weather (highs in the 70’s every day). I’m in my 50’s and heat sensitive too.
We went early June and the weather was perfect highs in the upper 70s, low 80s. Busy but not crazy busy.
April or October
Thank you everyone for all of your advice! September sounds like it is a winner!

text: Is it difficult to fly out of Milan to France, then fly back? (US passports) we are only thinking for a day or 2.

comments.comment_text: Ryanair
Difficult how? Both are Schengen countries so no passport checks if that's your concern.

Easy. Lots of low cost airlines flying everywhere. Not really worth it for one day though. Most of the airports are a bit outside of city centre so you need to allow transfer times, etc. plus the time you need to show up before your flight.
You can take the train into Paris and back

Unless you are flying from Linate which is really close to close, Malpensa or Bergamo are about 1 hour away from city centre. Buses run regularly and there is a train to Malpensa. You get cheap flights to France Ryanair and Easy jet and some others; check Skyscanner for prices and places they fly to. Going in and out is easy....I would maybe look at more than 1 day though as times of flights can vary & travel time to airports. Ryanair use Bergamo and Easy Jet use Malpensa. There are other low cost flights. Linate like I said is closest to Milan as its like a city airport but expect to pay more for flight.

Paris deserves at least 3-4 days, there's plenty to see. Moreover, if you are looking at a low cost airline pay very close attention to the baggage allowance - most low costs are worth it if you only carry a small backpack, and bringing any other luggage will cost you a lot
Not at all.

It's easy but I would take the train. Once you factor in arriving early, security, going to the airport in addition to flight time...it will probably work out to be about the same amount of total time. Plus its more comfortable.
Take the train, very easy!!
We took Vueling Airlines easy transition.
Would be an easy flight but I would make sure it wasn’t on a registered strike day. We flew out of Milan last Saturday and almost every flight was cancelled.
Easy!
Nope, very easy and much faster then the train. You can even store luggage at the airport that you don’t need for France

I'd do the train. Less.likely.for

text:

comments.comment_text:
Be prepared for 90-100 degree heat
Book tours through Viator so u can hopefully go in AM before it gets oppressively HOT
Drink lots of water

Buy tickets from official site not 3 rd party.

Back in the ‘70s, we never made reservations when traveling in Europe. We always made a reservation the day we arrived somewhere at the visitors’ kiosk at or near the train station. In those days, we mostly stayed at Bed and Breakfasts or small independent hotels. Is this feasible in this day and age during the shoulder season (trip planned for March or April? We’re planning a Eurail pass trip and prefer not to be tied down with a strict itinerary. Thanks!

comments.comment_text: It certainly is, but you may have to compromise on hotel or room configuration
Keep an eye on Booking.com.... You might even get some bargains!!
That was the 70s I was just in Italy 2022 for 21 days, you need to make your reservations ￼ ahead of time

We toured in Portugal & Spain for two weeks somewhat how you describe. In big cities / where we had a set date (e.g. prepaid Alhambra tour) we got reservations. Otherwise we stayed where the road took us, and that was very good. Being one of those '70s travelers myself, I note that the internet has somewhat supplanted the tourist offices. You can get very nice lodgings at the end of the day as the hotels try to fill rooms.
Yes it's the off season
I don't think it's possible as way more people are travelling. Eurail passes are a rip off just buy tickets as you go along
Good Luck 😲
Trains are still easy to book same day for popular destinations with multiple departures. Hotels not so much. Make cancellable reservations for accommodations

We did the same thing back in the 1970s. It was a great way to travel, I miss those days. But things have changed so much since then! I myself would not do it now in the high season. And I think shoulder season is as crowded now as peak season used to be. Personally I’d make reservations for accommodations in advance just to be sure to have a place to lay my head. You can probably find a room on arrival but my concern would be that what’s available would be either rock bottom cheap or else top tier luxury. Because it’s those two extremes that tend to be available at the last minute. I’d hate to have to arrive and find I’d have to sleep in a dingy dirty dump or else be faced with spending more than I can afford. To to protect myself I book ahead anymore no matter what time of year I travel.

I always have a general idea of where I’m going and how much time I’ll need in each place anyway so it just makes sense to make sure I’m able to stay in a nice place within my budget while I’m there.

Everyone’s different, though. You may not mind being surprised at your destination as much as I do.

text: I have a question and I hope you are kind. I’ve only been to Europe one other time and flew into Paris so this wasn’t an issue but my question is we are flying to Rome via Amsterdam. Will we have to get our luggage and go through customs or just our carryons and go through customs. I’m sure we will do the whole customs thing in Rome. Thank you

comments.comment_text:
Everything goes through customs
Look into Global Entry before u leave US
If I am correct you will go through customs in AMS and then your luggage gets rechecked
Yes, you have to go through customs on a layover in Amsterdam . Passengers are required to collect their checked baggage and pass through customs, before they can proceed to their connecting flight.

You will go through customs in the first place you land. So in this case, Amsterdam. Your luggage should be checked all the way through if it’s a through￼ ticket ( eg when you booked it said Rome as final destination). If however you bought separate tickets from Amsterdam to Rome, then you will have to collect your luggage and re-check. ￼ Customs does not get done again in Rome. ￼

You should clear customs and immigrations in Amsterdam where you will recheck your bags. Very easy. Always check the luggage tags the airlines attaches to your bag that your bag is directed to the correct and final destination.
We did not buy separate tickets to Rome.

Your baggage will be sent automatically to Rome, so you won’t need to collect your bags and check them in again in Amsterdam. You will go through passport control in Amsterdam and go through customs in Rome.
When you check your bags in the US, just ask and they will be able to tell you as well.

text: We are planning a trip to Italy with Globus Tours in Oct. 2023. On the Sunday that we will be there we will be in Cinque Terre. I have asked our Travel Agent about the ability to attend Mass on Sunday and her response was to ask the tour guide when we are there but if it is not possible to arrange it then we will have to skip going to Mass. As a practicing Catholic that is not an option. Have any other practicing Catholics in this group run into this problem. I would appreciate your advise.

comments.comment_text:
I’m not Catholic, but there are five different towns you are dealing with, and presumably moving between on the tour. It seems like the best course of action would be to obtain a schedule of the masses offered by the separate churches and then, perhaps you can arrange to attend one and meet up with the rest of the group later once you know the specific tour schedule.
Could you obtain contact information through the Catholic Church to inquire about specific schedules for individual churches?

There were lots of local Roman Catholic churches around the region, but do be aware that many smaller towns seemed to have their services on Saturdays or unusual times to enable the priests to serve all the communities. I am sure the local hotels and restaurants will be able to advise you. Blessings
Yes, you need to check with Globus to see what their schedule is.
You could also try for a Saturday evening Mass.

Thank you for your suggestions. I did get more detailed information from Globus and there is no way to arrange to attend Mass on either Sat. evening or Sun. morning due to the schedule. We would have to miss the entire tour schedule on Sun. The other problem is that I was unable to get a website for the churches so I can't even confirm Mass times. I checked Masstimes.org (in case someone was going to suggest that) and they have no Mass times listed. We have no paid for the tour yet so I may have to cancel and look elsewhere. First time in Italy so we are too nervous to plan the trip on our own.
There is a beautiful church, Church of St. Margaret of Antioch in Varnazza. As a practicing Catholic I can’t imagine you wouldn’t be welcome. Cinque Terre is a favorite destination when I travel.

I lived in Italy and Sunday mass will not be possible for the Tourist. It because most Italian Catholic Church has a Mass schedule 8,9,10 or 11 Am or 12 noon. If you are in the big Major city, then you might find it as you like it. But most of the Major city has a big church or Cathedral, you might find the good schedule for Sunday. Check your tour schedule and you might be able to attend the Mass if you happen to be in big city. I travel by myself and make my own schedule to find my time for Sunday Mass. Good Luck and enjoy your vacations!!!

One of the many reasons, we do not do tours. We find it so much better, a lot less expensive, and obviously more flexible when you do-it-yourself.
We have traveled to Italy once or twice a year for 23 years and have always done it ourselves. Nothing to fear, and we have had few regrets. For example, when we hiked Cinque Terre, we were able to look at the weather and pick the best day of the week for that. There are plenty of people here and in other places on the internet who can help you and provide answers to questions as you do the planning. I would rather travel with my wife than a group of strangers. When we have joined groups for short periods of time on such things as cruise excursions, there were always people who got lost or needed to make extra trips to the bathroom that kept us from maximum enjoyment. And, hoping you get to Vernazza, as crowded as it is when groups arrive. Here's a photo of the beautiful Catholic Church there.

There are Catholic run tour companies that might be a good fit! I don’t have any to recommend as I’ve always just planned my own trips, but they would definitely be aware of the Sunday mass obligation.

I'm not Catholic, but I am so impressed in this day and time that you are so committed. That is wonderful. I'm of the opinion that God will forgive you for missing mass once, but that's all it is--just my opinion. We loved our Globus Tour, so I'd hate for you to miss it.
I suggest you ask when you get to you hotel. They should be able to assist.
Ive never had a problem walking into any church in Italy whether mass was on or not. If youre timeframe works just rock up.

Again, thank you for all your responses. We decided to go ahead with the scheduled trip. Fortunately, we are in the same hotel from Saturday to Monday so if we need to skip the Sunday tour to go to Mass we will do that and just catch up with the group later in the day or on Monday. It will give us the opportunity to see what its like to plan a day on our own because, God willing, the next time we travel to Italy it will be without a tour company! 😃🙏

When Im travelling, I would attend a Livestream mass or even a recorded mass from my parish. I prefer that because at least it's in English.
I was in Milan Sept 2022, I attended a Sunday mass at the Duomo and it was in Italian. I was able to follow the readings on my cellphone. EWTN should have live and recorded masses.

There are so many places you could visit!

Desenzano: very beautiful and long frontlake, you can swim and enjoy a sunbath, the center has many bars to drink.

Peschiera: River Mincio entering in Garda lake gives it a spectacular blu/green colour that will give you breathtaking pictures. Many many restaurants along the "canal" with a fantastic view, there's a little touristic train you can hope on to tour the frontlake if you don't want to walk.

Riva del Garda: you must take the transparent lift that leads on the hill where there is an ancient fort to visit and a modern restaurant to drink and eat, obviously the view is incredible.

Bardolino: there's LIFE in Bardolino! Restaurants, bars, hotels, frontlake, flowers! Everything.

Limone del Garda. A beautiful small jewel, I suggest you get there by ferry early in the morning because it gets dark quicker there ( the mountains cover the sun). You can hire electric bicycles and circle on what I think is the longest European suspended frontlake the visit the center for lunch ( many fish restaurants), souvenir shopping.

Finally Malcesine: I personally love the beach of Malcesine the water is so clean and transparent, then you can visit the castle

Enjoy

text: Watertown, Venice

Bologna we loved you just as much second time around ❤. Was the perfect start to our 6 week trip to acclimatise to the heat and settle in after our long trip from Australia. Yes it is hot but if you choose Italy in summer you have to expect this -if you don't tolerate heat well choose another time . . We got going early, had plenty of stops for iced water and of course aperol spritz 🤣 and embraced the Siesta . We still managed 25 to 33000 steps a day as we find walking the best way to discover a city . Last time we were here we did all the touristy things which were fabulous but this time we slowed down and just enjoyed beautuful Bologna .We did do the 6km walk up a hill to Maddona di luca along the world's longest portico and 600 archways .This is not for the faint-hearted we are pretty fit but it was a challenge in the heat (we went early ) .You can get a little train up and back but my partner wouldn't get on it as said it looked like a kids train 🤣 so walk back we did but aperol stops along the way and much easier downhill . Restaurants we didn't need to book but we did as Italians seem to love when you make a reservation. Vicolo Colombina a Michelin restaurant was fabulous and very reasonably priced and La Traviata a family run restaurant had great service,food and wonderful wine list . For cocktails Guero a must tecommended by one of the members of this group ..we would never of found it but so glad we did why this group is so great thanks Scott ....my favourite time of the day was an early walk on my own watching the city wake and all the locals heading off to work and having a cappuccino alongside them ☕ now for our next adventure 9 days in Sardinia can't wait to see if it's as good as we have heard .

Murano glass… I bought back jewelry gifts and everyone loved them.
Bought myself some too 😊
Saw some lovely wall clocks in a little place but would not be able to tell you directions. They were lovely and wishes now I had one

I bought a cd from a group of street musicians in Florence, not knowing if it would work at home, but it did! Beautiful! It brought back the "feel" of Florence every time I listened to the beautiful music.

In via dei Gucciardini, if you keep walking straight from Ponte Vecchio towards the Pitti Palace, on the right, before the Pitti Palace there is a shop D.Vers@ with products of local artisans. Similar is Florence Factory at the end of Via dei Neri, on the left, walking from Piazza della Signoria.

I’d recommend skipping the leather market and heading straight for the leather school! It’s accessible for all price ranges and they will engrave your initials for free! Other than that, Pinocchio is huge in Florence! Going towards the Pitti Palace from Ponte Vecchio, you’ll come across the Pinocchio Store on the right side of the road. Florence also has several Il Papiro shops with handmade stationary and other items with the marbled paper design.
Leather bookmarks from the Leather School.
The best gift I ever bought in Florence were beautiful coin purses made of paper.

text:
We are heading to Rome/Venice/Florence March 7-20, 2024.
I have seen thousands of pictures taken during the summer. ￼ I’d be interested to see what it looks like in March. Could you please photo dump pictures from ear￼ly March?
I want to see clothes, sky, and landscape.

comments.comment_text: March is usually chilly and often rainy in Italy. Not too cold but not full blown spring either. We normally wear light jackets, trench coats during the day and in the evenings we wear heavier jackets; scarves are always worn.
Maybe try googling Italy in March so you can get statistics cause based on where you are In Italy, weather can be quiet different.

Late March/early April 2023 were particularly cold/rainy. I had to wear a thicker jacket. I hadn't brought one, but my mom (who lives in Rome) bought me one as a present (at a streetmarket, 25 euros). It got warmer around April 15th and I was only wearing a t-shirt, hoodie and thin jacket. But it varies a lot, depending on the year, so better check when your trip is approaching. I will upload some pictures in the following comments.
Cecilia Christine Costantini
Cecilia Christine Costantini
Cecilia Christine Costantini
Cecilia Christine Costantini
This is the thick jacket I was wearing

I went to Venice in late March 22 and had absolutely beautiful, unseasonably warm weather. No rain at all, I wore short sleeves all day, and i would eat at night outside with a light jacket. I took a chance going in March and for me to was worth it. It was absolutely perfect weather. Perfect temperature to travel and walk around and site see.
We are thinking of March 15-29, 2024. From what I read 2022 was great, and 2023 had lots of rain.
It varies A LOT.you could get an early spring type of weather or late winter one.Check the weather just before leaving on meteo.it
Jackets boots and umbrellas ☔️.

text: Hi everyone, just asking does anyone have any recommendations for accommodation in Sorrento that would be wheelchair friendly thanks, asking for a friend, appartments or Hotel thanks in advance 🙂

comments.comment_text: Older apartments likely will not be an option. Ours had a few steps into and the elevator was tiny and likely wouldn’t fit a wheelchair. Might be safest to stick with hotels or any newer buildings.
As a wheelchair user, I would stick with hotels. They're much more likely to have elevators.
Hotel Plaza Sorrento

text:
Coming to Europe for the 1st time with my 7 year old daughter (single mum) and thinking to include Italy into my trip. I will have 5 nights available to spend in Italy. But where in Italy is my question?
Was thinking amalfi coast? We love beaches, pools nice views, food? Please tell me what you think? I have no idea what I’m in for 🤷‍♀️

comments.comment_text: You can get all that in most parts of Italy. Try Tuscany, it has all that; long coastline, beautiful cities and towns, great countryside and nature, majestic villas with pools, great food and the region is well connected with trains and has two major airports (Pisa and Firenze).
Tuscany is a runner but also Portofino area or Lake Como or Lake Garda. Other option is Venetian coastline where you can combine a beach holiday with visiting Venice and Verona.
